properties.StationName: Nooksack R. abv the Middle Fork
properties.StationDescription: The Nooksack watershed contains the 3 (North, Middle, and South) forks of the Nooksack River, which drain approximately 1,250 square miles of land.  This station is located on the left bank of the North Fork at the Mosquito Lake Road Bridge crossing near river mile 40.8. The data collected from this site will be used to assess groundwater contribution to the North Fork flows in combination with an existing US Geological Survey (USGS) gage. The North Fork Nooksack River supports populations of coho, steelhead, chinook, chum, char, pink and sockeye salmon as well as cutthroat, rainbow and eastern brook trout.
properties.StationComments: Due to budget cuts, this station is slated for removal effective October 1, 2010

properties.StationDescription: Hutchinson Creek is a tributary of the South Fork Nooksack River.  The origins of the creek begin near Bowman Mountain in the Cascade foothills and drain to the confluence near river mile 10.3 of the South Fork. Data collected at this station will be used to develop a relationship between flow and habitat for salmon recovery.  Hutchinson Creek supports populations of steelhead and coho salmon as well as cutthroat trout.

The headwaters of the Sumas River begin in northern Whatcom County and the river flows across the border into Canada.  The objective of this gage is to develop a hydrograph that will be useful in international flow issues.  The Sumas River supports populations of coho, steelhead, chinook, and chum salmon as well as cutthroat trout.
properties.StationComments: Due to budget cuts, monitoring at this station has been discontinued effective October 1, 2009.

properties.StationDescription: The Nooksack watershed contains the 3 (North, Middle, and South) forks of the Nooksack River, which drain approximately 1,250 square miles of land.  This station is located on the left bank of the South Fork at the Potter Road Bridge crossing near river mile 1.8. The data collected from this site will be used to assess groundwater contribution to the South Fork flows in combination with an existing US Geological Survey (USGS) gage. The South Fork Nooksack River supports populations of coho, steelhead, chinook, chum, char, pink and sockeye salmon as well as cutthroat trout.
properties.StationComments: Due to loss of local funding support, flow at this station is no longer reported. If you have any questions or concerns please contact Brad Hopkins, (brad.hopkins@ecy.wa.gov) phone (360) 407-6686.

properties.StationName: M.F. Nooksack R. abv Clearwater Cr.
properties.StationDescription: The Nooksack watershed contains the 3 (North, Middle, and South) forks of the Nooksack River, which drain approximately 1,250 square miles of land.  The Middle Fork gage is located at the bridge crossing, on the right bank of the Middle Fork at river mile 9.5 off of Forest Road 38.   The Nooksack Indian Tribe will assist the City of Bellingham in managing diversions for maintenance of habitat and fish passage above the Middle Fork diversion dam.  This gage will support that effort.  The Middle Fork Nooksack River supports populations of coho, steelhead, chinook, chum, char, pink and sockeye salmon as well as cutthroat and rainbow trout.
properties.StationComments: Due to budget cuts, monitoring at this station has been discontinued effective October 1, 2009.

properties.StationDescription: Bar Creek is a higher elevation tributary to the North Fork Nooksack River.  The confluence with the North Fork is directly below Nooksack Falls.  The objective for the Bar Creek gage is to gain hydrograph data for a glacially dominated creek. Bar Creek supports populations of eastern brook trout.
properties.StationComments: This station sustained damage during flooding in October 2003.  Due to a washout on the Wells Creek Road (FR 33), the station is currently inaccessible.  Repairs will be made as soon as possible.

properties.StationDescription: Maple Creek is a higher elevation tributary that flows southward from Silver Lake before converging with the North Fork Nooksack River near river mile 49.7.  Data collected at this station will be used to develop a relationship between flow and habitat for salmon recovery.  This station is located on the right bank at Nuguaâ€™lum Park, just downstream from the small bridge. The lower section of Maple Creek supports populations of coho, steelhead, chinook, chum, char, pink and sockeye salmon as well as cutthroat and rainbow trout.
properties.StationComments: This station was permanently removed in November 2008 due to substantial beaver activity at the site, which was making the stage-discharge relationship extremely volatile.

properties.StationDescription: Anderson Creek is a tributary to the mainstem Nooksack River.  The confluence is just west of the town of Deming.  Data obtained from the Anderson Creek gage will be useful in assisting fisheries management projects.  Anderson Creek supports populations of coho, steelhead, chinook, and chum salmon as well as cutthroat trout.
properties.StationComments: Due to budget cuts, monitoring at this station has been discontinued effective October 1, 2009.

properties.StationDescription: Kamm Slough is a lowland tributary to the mainstem Nooksack River.  The confluence is just south of the town of Lynden. The data obtained from the Kamm Slough gage will be useful in assisting habitat restoration and other instream flow projects. Kamm Slough supports populations of coho salmon and cutthroat trout.
properties.StationComments: Due to budget cuts, monitoring at this station has been discontinued effective October 1, 2009.

properties.StationDescription: Bertrand Creek is a lowland tributary that flows from southern B.C., primarily through agricultural areas, and drains into the mainstem Nooksack River at river mile 12.5.  Bertrand Creek is the focus of management efforts to improve habitat and instream flows under the Comprehensive Irrigation District Management Plan (CIDMP) and WRIA 01 management.  The data will be used to assist in assessing effectiveness of management projects. The gage is located on the left bank at the Rathbone Road Bridge crossing located approximately 1.5 miles from the confluence with the mainstem Nooksack River.  Bertrand Creek supports populations of coho, steelhead, chinook, chum, and sockeye salmon as well as cutthroat trout.
properties.StationComments: Water levels at this station begin to be influenced by backwater from the Nooksack River when the gage height at the USGS gage on the Nooksack River at Ferndale is above 9.5 feet

properties.StationDescription: Tenmile Creek is a lowland agricultural tributary that drains into the mainstem Nooksack River at river mile 7.0.  Tenmile Creek is the focus of management efforts to improve habitat and instream flows under the Comprehensive Irrigation District Management Plan (CIDMP) and WRIA 01 management.  The data will be used to assist in assessing effectiveness of management projects. The gage is near the West Laurel Bridge crossing approximately 2.8 miles from the confluence with the mainstem Nooksack River. Tenmile Creek supports populations of coho, steelhead, chinook, and chum salmon as well as cutthroat trout.

properties.StationDescription: Dakota Creek is a lowland stream that flows directly into Drayton Harbor in Puget Sound.  The objective of the Dakota Creek gage is to better understand the hydrology of a lowland creek with direct flow to Puget Sound.   Dakota Creek supports populations of coho, chinook, and chum salmon as well as cutthroat trout.

California Creek is a lowland stream that flows directly into Drayton Harbor in Puget Sound.  The objective of the California Creek gage is to better understand the hydrology of a lowland creek with direct flow to the Puget Sound.   California Creek supports populations of coho salmon and cutthroat trout.

properties.StationDescription: Squalicum Creek is an urban stream that flows through Bellingham, WA and drains directly into Bellingham Bay.  The objective of the Squalicum Creek gage is to characterize an urban hydrograph and the associated restoration actions.  Squalicum Creek supports populations of coho, steelhead, chinook, chum, and sockeye salmon as well as cutthroat trout.
properties.StationComments: Due to budget cuts, monitoring at this station has been discontinued effective October 1, 2009.

properties.StationDescription: Friday Creek is a tributary to the Samish River. The creek originates at the outlet of Lake Samish near Nulle Road and flows through farmland, rural residential land and forested slopes on the north side of the Lower Samish River valley.  The gage at Friday Creek is three-quarters of a mile upstream of the confluence with the Samish River and about half a mile below the Samish Hatchery. The Samish Hatchery produces chinook salmon. The creek also supports steelhead, coho, and chum salmon as well as native trout species.
Ambient water quality station. Take Stewart/Hoad Road to Hoad Road to Laventure Road to Swan Road to bridge.

properties.StationName: E.F. Nookachamps Cr. @ Beaver Lake Rd.
properties.StationDescription: East Fork Nookachamps joins with West Fork Nookachamps and becomes Nookachamps Creek. The main stem of Nookachamps Creek is a tributary of the Skagit River. The creek flows from its headwaters through farmland and forested slopes of the Cascade foothills on the south side of the lower Skagit River valley. East Fork Nookachamps Creek supports coho, chum, chinook, and pink salmon as well as steelhead. It also supports resident rainbow and cutthroat trout. The gage is located on the upstream side of the bridge on Beaver Lake Road. It is a few feet downstream of the confluence with Cold Spring Creek and is about three miles above the confluence with the main stem of Nookachamps Creek.

Hansen Creek originates on the southwest side of Lyman Hill and runs south to the Skagit River just east of Sedro-Woolley. The creek runs through mostly forested, rural residential, and agricultural lands before entering the Skagit River. Hansen Creek supports chinook, coho, chum, and pink salmon, as well as steelhead and other native trout species. The gage on Hansen Creek is located on the left bank downstream of the footbridge over the creek in the Northern State Recreation Area in Sedro Woolley, WA.

properties.StationDescription: The South Fork Stillaguamish River originates from the northern slopes of Del Campo and Morning Star Peaks in central Snohomish County. It flows west and northwest and then meets with the North Fork Stillaguamish River near Arlington, WA. South Fork Stillaguamish supports chinook, coho, chum, and pink salmon, as well as steelhead and bull trout, along with other native trout species.  The gage on the South Fork Stillaguamish River is on the left bank at the south end of the Jordan Road Bridge near Granite Falls, WA.

properties.StationDescription: The North Fork Stillaguamish River originates from several branches near Finney Peak. It flows south and then west through the western foothills of the Cascade mountain range. Along the way it gathers many tributaries of which the Boulder River and Deer Creek are some of the largest. North Fork Stillaguamish supports chinook, coho, chum, and pink salmon, as well as steelhead and bull trout, along with other native trout species.  The gage on the North Fork Stillaguamish River is at the north end of the Whitman Road bridge near Oso, WA.

properties.StationDescription: Squire Creek originates near Whitehorse Mountain, elevation 6,530 feet, to the west, Summit Mountain, 5,480 feet, to the east, and Squire Creek Pass to the south.  This is a scenic and recreational area that includes a variety of trails and camping facilities. The headwater region of Squire Creek, near Whitehorse Mountain, is presently a candidate for consideration in the National Wilderness Preservation System.  Squire Creek is a third order stream, a large tributary to the N.F. Stillaguamish River, and enters the river on the left bank near river mile 31.2.  Squire Creek drains a watershed of 25 square miles and is about 9.5 miles in long, with 7 tributaries adding 16.5 linear stream miles.  The upper 4.5 miles of the creek are in the Mt. Baker National Forest.  Squire Creek offers about 8 miles of stream for salmon use.  Tributaries offer an additional 5.5 miles of habitat.  Chinook spawn mainly in Squire Creek, while pink, chum, coho and steelhead use the mainstem plus each accessible tributary.  Juvenile salmon rear in all accessible stream areas.

properties.StationDescription: The Big Quilcene River drains a basin of approximately 70 square miles. The watershed is primarily under federal ownership. The Big Quilcene system includes 18.9 miles of mainstem channel, and 81.9 miles of tributary streams. The largest tributaries in the Big Quilcene River sub-basin are Penny Creek, Townsend Creek and Tunnel Creek. Tunnel Creek, the Big Quilcene River and Townsend Creek have headwaters located in high elevation areas, and their runoff is derived primarily from snowmelt and rainfall. Penny Creekâ€™s headwaters are located at a lower elevation and its stream flow is primarily influenced by rainfall. The headwater tributaries of the Big Quilcene River are extremely high gradient, highly confined channels. The middle reaches below River Mile 4.8 are confined, moderate gradient channels with widened floodplains. Low gradient, unconfined channels characterize the lower 2.5 miles, while the lower 1.0 mile meanders across a broad alluvial fan.
properties.StationComments: Funding for this station was discontinued by the City of Port Townsend effective December 31, 2013.

properties.StationDescription: Chimacum Creek flows north out of two glacially carved lowland valleys in northeastern Jefferson County to the southern end of Port Townsend Bay, at Irondale. The East Fork and West Fork, together with small tributaries, comprise 29.5 miles of stream that converge into the mainstem at RM 2.7. The area of the watershed is approximately 37 square miles. The East and West forks represent one-third and two-thirds, respectively, of the total flow. The East Fork starts in the flat-bottomed Chimacum Valley, approximately four and one-half miles upstream from the confluence point at an elevation of 180 ft. The West Fork is longer, reaching into the uplands southeast of Discovery Bay.

The Jimmycomelately Creek watershed encompasses 15.4 square miles, with a vertical drop of approximately 2,500 feet over 19.8 miles.  The stream originates in Olympic National Forest, flowing through steep timberland for most of its length.  The gradient diminishes to 1% or less in the lower 1.5 miles of the creek, and land use transitions to agricultural practices. The lower 2.0 miles of the creek supports populations of coho salmon, steelhead trout and summer chum salmon.  The summer chum salmon are listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act.  The average annual precipitation in the watershed varies from approximately 16 inches per year near the City of Sequim to nearly 35 inches per year at Mt. Zion, the highest point of the watershed.  The average precipitation intensity, which governs the recurrence interval of the peak flood, is 2 inches in 24 hours.

This gauge was installed at the request of the Dungeness River Management Team and the project partners in the Jimmycomelately Creek Ecosystem Restoration Project.  Jimmycomelately Creek was diverted in the early 1900â€™s from its historic location into a straightened channel, to provide agricultural land for the local residents.  This diversion disconnected the stream from its historic floodplain and wetland complex as well as displaced it from its historic estuary.  The restoration project is an ambitious attempt to restore the creek to its historic condition through reconstruction of a meandering channel in the historic floodplain, and reconnection of the channel to the historic estuary.
properties.StationComments: This station was moved to the new restoration channel on June 14th, 2005. The station is now identified as 17C075.

properties.StationDescription:
In the early 20th century Jimmycomelately Creek was disconnected from its floodplain, ditched and pushed to the edge of the valley. In 2005, one of the largest stream channel restoration projects in Puget Sound was completed on Jimmycomelately Creek. The restoration of Jimmycomelately Creek moved the channel back to the valley center, excavated a floodplain and reconnected the tidal energy of its estuary to the mouth of the creek. In addition, a road and log yard were removed from the estuary, restoring nearly 20 acres of saltmarsh.

The Department of Ecology has monitored flows on Jimmycomelately Creek since October 1999 and has maintained a near-real time stream gage since August of 2002.  In June 2005, with the restoration of the channel to its original location, Ecology moved the gage to its new location on the restored channel. Flow data from before the completion of the restoration project in June 2005 can be found at the 17C070 Jimmycomelately Creek nr Mouth web page by using the 'show historical' tab at the top of the station list on this page.
properties.StationComments: Due to budget cuts, this station has been removed effective October 1, 2013.  For more information contact Brad Hopkins at brad.hopkins@ecy.wa.gov

properties.StationDescription: The Little Quilcene River basin of approximately 40 square miles includes 12.2 miles of mainstem channel, and 81.2 miles of tributary streams. The headwaters of the Little Quilcene River originate above 4,400 feet on the north slopes of Mt. Townsend and its runoff is derived from both rainfall and snowmelt. The upper watershed down to River Mile 6.6 is within the Olympic National Forest and is steeply dissected with high gradient, confined stream channels. The lower seven miles runs through glacial sediments, siltstone and sandstone. This lower valley, including the floodplain, has been developed for domestic and agricultural use, and timber harvest. Along the Little Quilcene River, below RM 3.0, 60 percent of the riparian zone is developed. The lower 0.8 miles have been diked and the banks armored to protect property in the floodplain. The Little Quilcene River discharges to Quilcene Bay approximately one mile north of the mouth of the Big Quilcene. The largest tributaries in the Little Quilcene River sub-basin are Howe Creek, Ripley Creek and Leland Creek.

Snow Creek drains a watershed of 23.1 square miles and includes 30 miles of mainstem and tributary stream channel.  Like Salmon Creek, Snow Creek also originates near Mt. Zion in the Olympic range, and generally drains east to the Strait of Juan De Fuca at the south end of Discovery Bay.  The mouth of Snow Creek is immediately east of the mouth of Salmon Creek.  Historically, Snow Creek was a tributary of Salmon Creek and the confluence was approximately 0.6 RM upstream of Discovery Bay. However, Snow Creek was dredged and relocated to the east side of the valley and now discharges directly to Discovery Bay.

The Salmon Creek basin is approximately 18.8 square miles.  Originating near Mt. Zion in the Olympic range, Salmon Creek generally drains east to the Strait of Juan De Fuca at the south end of Discovery Bay, immediately west of the mouth of Snow Creek. The geology of the upper basin is predominantly basalt and glacial outwash. It is less vulnerable to mass wasting and erosion than the adjacent Snow Creek headwaters, because basalt and breccia underlies this upper canyon reach. The lower valley is characterized by sand, gravel, and clay deposited during glaciation. Material transported from the upper watershed forms a broad alluvial fan.  Originally, Salmon Creek was joined by Snow Creek at RM 0.6, but Snow Creek now flows separately to the estuary through an artificial channel. Salmon Creek has 8.7 miles of mainstem and 21.8 miles of tributary stream channel.
properties.StationComments: This station was relocated 0.5 mi downstream in February 2013.  The new station is 17F050 - Salmon Cr. @ WDFW.

properties.StationDescription: The Headwaters for Tarboo Creek begin 5 miles north of the inlet to Tarboo Bay at an elevation of 600 ft, and drain south to the head of Dabob Bay. A branch of the creek near the headwaters begins about one-quarter mile from Tarboo Lake. There is no mapped inlet or outlet to this lake. Combining all mapped tributaries with the main creek results in a total length for Tarboo Creek of 14 miles. It drains a basin of 12.4 square miles. The upper reaches have intact, second-growth forest in the riparian zone. Some beaver ponds are present. The lower 0.5 mile is a high-quality, forested reach which was protected as critical habitat by WDFW in 1999. The Department of Natural Resources Natural Heritage Program also protects estuarine wetlands and forested slopes on the east and west sides of the bay.

The main stem of Thorndyke Creek begins in the northern region of the sub-basin at Sandy Shore Lake, and drains south to Thorndyke Bay on the east side of the Toandos Peninsula. The drainage area is 12.1 square miles  for Thorndyke Creek and has a number of wetlands and seasonal lakes in the highland areas. Combining flow from Sandy Shore Lake with additional inflow from tributaries results in a stream of 13 plus miles in length.

properties.StationDescription:
The Dungeness River basin lies in the northeastern Olympic peninsula of Washington State.  The Dungeness River flows in a northerly direction from the rugged mountain peaks of Olympic National Park to the Strait of Juan De Fuca at Dungeness Bay.  The upper portion of the river flows through steep narrow canyons while the lower ten miles is characterized by gently sloping plains. 

The Dungeness River at Schoolhouse Rd. stream gage is located about four miles north of Sequim Washington at the Anderson Rd./ Schoolhouse Bridge crossing (approximate River Mile 0.75) near the community of Dungeness 

Over the last 25 years the population of the Dungeness valley including the city of Sequim, has increased dramatically, altering the river environment.  One of the environmental concerns associated with the watershed has been the increase in Fecal Coliform bacteria in Dungeness Bay.  These increasing bacteria levels have led to recent shellfish harvest closures.

In November of 1999 the Washington Department of Ecology, in cooperation with the Jamestown S'Kllallam Tribe and Clallam County began conducting a water quality study to identify bacterial sources that contribute to the poor water quality in the bay. Water quality scientists chose to monitor streams that enter Dungeness Bay in the vicinity of the closure area, including the Dungeness River.  

The Department of Ecology's Stream Hydrology Unit (SHU) was requested to provide the flow information for this project and installed continuous stage-height and temperature recording equipment near the mouth of the Dungeness River.  A series of stream discharge measurements, expressed in cubic feet per second (cfs), have been made throughout the course of the project. A rating curve was determined by plotting these measured discharges against their corresponding stages at the times they were measured. The rating curves and their associated regression equations are then used to predict flows (discharge) at a given stage.

This water quality project was concluded in November of 2000.  However, the Dungeness River Management Team has requested SHU continue monitoring flow on the river in order to better manage issues facing the Dungeness watershed.

In the Spring of 2002, in cooperation with the USGS, the Department of Ecology upgraded the station to transmit data every three hours back to Ecology headquarters.

Morse Creek is an independent drainage located between the Dungeness and Elwha rivers on the North Slope of the Olympic Peninsula in Washington State. The main stem of Morse Creek is 16.3 miles long with a total drainage area of approximately 57 square miles. The head waters of the creek range from 4,000 to 5,000 feet elevation in the Hurricane Ridge area of Olympic National Park and flows in a northerly direction to its mouth at the Strait of Juan De Fuca about five miles east of Port Angeles in Clallam County. The two largest tributaries are Maiden Creek (confluence at river mile 10.5) and Lake Creek (confluence at river mile 7.5). The City of Port Angeles diversion dam is located at river mile7. 

Morse Creek is relatively high-gradient, steep and fast flowing throughout its length. Even the lower reaches are characterized by long, steep riffles. The average gradient for its entire length is greater than 6 percent. 

Morse Creek has been known for its valuable salmon runs and is currently considered a high priority candidate for salmon habitat restoration.


In August of 2000 the Department of Ecology's Stream Hydrology Unit installed a flow monitoring station near the mouth of Morse Creek at the request of the Elwha/Morse Watershed Management Team.  The management team is comprised of a diverse coalition of stakeholder caucuses including Clallam County, the City of Port Angeles, the (Lower) Elwha Kllallam Tribe, Department of Ecology as well as private landowners, business/commercial interests, fisheries and recreation interests and environmentalists among others. The group was founded in response to the Watershed Planning Act, WA RCW Title 90, Chapter 90.82.  Presently they are early in the planning process, gathering, analyzing and organizing data.  One of the tasks assigned to the planning team is to develop a water budget and water balance analysis.  As a result, Ecology's Stream Hydrology Unit was asked to supply flow information to assist in this effort.  


The Ecology flow monitoring station is equipped with a data logger and a pressure transducer for recording and measuring stage-height at fifteen-minute intervals.  After taking several discharge measurements, a rating curve is determined by plotting these measured discharges against the stage heights at the time of the measurements. The rating curve and its associated regression equation, applied to the recorded stage-height measurements, produce a record of predicted flows.
properties.StationComments: Due to budget cuts, this station is slated for removal effective October 1, 2010

properties.StationDescription: The Elwha-Morse Management Team (EMMT) suggested this station based upon Morse Creekâ€™s importance to salmon recovery efforts in Clallam County.  Although a gauge is also located near the mouth of Morse Creek, EMMT was interested in understanding the flow regime in the â€œbypassâ€ reach between the City of Port Angelesâ€™ diversion dam and hydroelectric facility.  This section of the river has been identified as important salmon and steelhead spawning habitat.

In April 1998, the Washington State Department of Ecology and the members of the Dungeness River Water Users Association formalized a memorandum creating a temporary trust water right under WA RCW Title 90, Chapter 90.42. This agreement describes the process of creating a permanent trust water right for future irrigation and instream flows and states that no more than 50% of the flow of the Dungeness River may be diverted. To assist the Dungeness River Water Users Association with the implementation of this agreement, Ecology has installed five flow monitoring stations on selected irrigation ditches. In cooperation with the irrigation districts,  Parshall flumes and  near real-time flow monitoring equipment has been installed at the CCD Irrigation Ditch (above the split), at the Independent Irrigation Company Ditch (at the fish screen), at the Agnew Irrigation Ditch (at the fish screen), at the Sequim Prairie/ Dungeness District Ditch (at the fish screen), and at the Highland Irrigation District Ditch (at the fish screen). Construction of these sites was completed in the Spring of 2001.

In April 1998, the Washington State Department of Ecology and the members of the Dungeness River Water Users Association formalized a memorandum creating a temporary trust water right under WA RCW Title 90, Chapter 90.42. This agreement describes the process of creating a permanent trust water right for future irrigation and instream flows and states that no more than 50% of the flow of the Dungeness River may be diverted. To assist the Dungeness River Water Users Association with the implementation of this agreement, Ecology has installed five flow monitoring stations on selected irrigation ditches. The headwaters of Siebert Creek are located in the foothills of the Olympic Mountains, within Olympic National Park.  Siebert Creek is 12.4 miles in length, draining an area of 19.5 square miles as it flows north into the Strait of Juan de Fuca. The elevation of the upper watershed reaches up to 3,800 feet, with the upper reaches of the stream typically being steep and incised.  Although remaining in a confined floodplain, the gradient diminishes in the lower reaches, as the stream flows through lands managed for a mixture of timber harvest, agricultural uses, and rural housing.

The Dungeness River Management Team suggested Seibert Creek as a location for a gauging location in order to maintain the long, historical record of flows in the basin.  The USGS operated a gauge on the creek from 1952-1969 before ultimately abandoning the site.  Since that time, other groups have periodically monitored stream flows to maintain the record to the extent possible.
properties.StationComments: This station has been discontinued due to repeated equipment damage and major channel morphology changes.

properties.StationDescription: Ennis Creek is the smallest of the snow fed streams on the North Olympic Peninsula.  The watershed encompasses approximately 10.5 square miles, with the headwaters located at approximately 6,000 feet in elevation near Klahane Ridge in the Olympic National Park.  Considered the healthiest of the Port Angeles urban streams, Ennis Creek is over 8.5 miles in length and supports populations of coho salmon, steelhead, and cutthroat trout.  Ennis Creek is generally steep and confined.  In its upper reaches, cobble and large gravel, with intermittent outcrops of bedrock dominate the channel bed.  The lower portion of the creek is channelized and constrained between the former Rayonier Mill site and the Port Angeles wastewater treatment plant.  The mill is currently being dismantled and cleanup of the site is underway.

The basin also supports a unique genetic strain of rainbow trout.

properties.StationDescription: The McDonald Creek basin lies in the northeastern Olympic peninsula of Washington State, between the Dungeness River watershed and the Morse Creek watershed.  The basin encompasses 23 square miles, with the upper reaches found in Olympic National Park at elevations of up to 5,060 feet.  The river flows north from mountains for 13.6 miles before reaching the Strait of Juan de Fuca.  A falls creates a barrier to anadromous fish at river mile 5.2.  Also, a gravel bar sometimes delays salmon entry at the mouth during low flow periods. The gradient is predominately steep throughout the basin, although it moderates in the lower reaches.  The stream channel is well defined, and bank vegetation is generally favorable for salmon except in the heaviest areas of residential development. During the irrigation season, McDonald Creek is used by the irrigation districts to transport Dungeness River water for irrigation purposes. Up to 5 cfs of Dungeness River water is diverted into McDonald Creek at river mile 4.1. The water is then removed again at river mile 3.2. During low flow periods, Dungeness River water could represent a significant portion of the flow in this reach.

properties.StationDescription:
Bingham Creek is a tributary to the East Fork Satsop River at river mile 17.5 in Mason County.  Draining approximately 35 square miles of commercial forest lands, the headwaters of Bingham Creek emanate from the forested slopes of South Mountain, the southernmost peak of the Olympic mountains.    

Coho salmon and steelhead spawn and rear in Bingham Creek.  The Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) spawn, rear, and release both coho and steelhead from their hatchery facility located at the confluence of Bingham Creek and the East Fork Satsop River.  WDFW also operates a research facility located upstream of the hatchery which monitors adult and juvenile salmon population trends. 

The Ecology flow monitoring station, established in September 2000, is equipped with a Design Analysis Model 500 data logger and a Design Analysis Model H-310 pressure transducer for recording and measuring stage-height at fifteen minute intervals.  The station is also equipped with a staff gage.  Recently, a Design Analysis Model H-219 telephone modem has been installed.  The modem allows SHU to download the data at regular intervals, typically daily, and post â€œreal-timeâ€ data to our webpage. 

As of March 2002, a total of 9 discrete flow measurements have been conducted at the station.  Using the continuous instrument records of water pressure, the stage height(s), and the discrete flows, an accurate relationship between these variables has been established.  This relationship, or rating curve, has been used to create a predicted record of stream discharge at fifteen minute intervals since the station was installed.  In addition, a water temperature probe incorporated into the H-310 pressure transducer has enabled us to create a continuous thermograph for the site.

properties.StationDescription:
The Grays River streamflow gage is located at the historic covered bridge. This gage provides a reliable measurement of water elevation (â€œstageâ€) for the middle reach of the Grays River. Wahkiakum County funds the operation of this streamflow gage and the National Weather Serviceâ€™s Grays River flood forecast is based on this stage record.
The Grays River begins in the Willapa Hills and empties into the Columbia River. Huckleberry and Long ridges divide the headwaters of the Grays River from the upper Chehalis, Willapa, and Naselle river watersheds. The Grays River streamflow gage is located 10.5 miles upstream of the confluence with the Columbia River. The watershed area above the gage is roughly 94 square miles. The mouth of the Grays River opens into Grays Bay adjacent to the mouth of the Deep River.
There is an additional 30 square miles of tributary stream watersheds that drain into the Grays River downstream of this streamflow gage. This lower watershed is 24% of the total Grays River watershed area.  Most farms and residences on the Grays River are located in the lower watershed.

The Grays River supports chinook salmon, coho salmon, chum salmon, pink salmon, and steelhead.

properties.StationDescription: The station on the Tucannon River near Marengo is located on the left bank just downstream from the county bridge. Installed and powered up in early June of 2003, this continuously recording, telemetered station is designed to provide near real-time discharge information by transmitting data on regular intervals to the GOES West satellite, from there the data follows an established path before being received at the Washington Department of Ecology headquarters in Olympia, Washington.  The Tucannon River is one of the few Snake River tributaries in this area which contains a spring run of chinook salmon, Oncorhynchus tshawytscha.

Pataha Creek is a relatively large right-bank tributary to the Tucannon River approximately 1 mile downstream from the station.  Pataha Creek runs generally northward from itâ€™s headwaters in the northern Blue Mountains and then turns westward near the communities of Pataha and Pomeroy where it drains some of the most fertile agricultural lands in Washington State.

properties.StationDescription: Alpowa Creek is a left bank tributary to the Snake River approximately 6 miles downstream from Clarkston, Washington.  The headwaters of Alpowa Creek are in the northern foothills of the Blue Mountains, from there the creek flows northeasterly to its confluence with the Snake.  Major tributaries to Alpowa Creek include Pow Wah Kee Creek, Page Creek, and Stember Creek.  The station is located on the right bank of Alpowa creek between the Old Chief Timothy bridge and the Highway 12 bridge on the parking lot of the Department of Transportation Interpretive Site.

Almota Creek is a right bank tributary to the Snake River just downstream from Lower Granite Dam.  The station itself is located within the highway 194 right-of-way on the left bank just upstream from the 194 crossing.  Despite its small size and relatively steep gradient, Almota Creek supports a run of steelhead which were observed this past spring spawning below, in, and above the large culvert which passes Almota creek beneath highway 194.

properties.StationDescription:
This station is part of Ecologyâ€™s Water Acquisition Monitoring Project.  This station is one of two on South Fork Cowiche Creek.  Another is located upstream.  The purpose of this station is to verify that water is actually returned in stream subsequent to the acquisition of up-stream water rights.  In addition to stream discharge information water temperature data is also being collected.  

There has been considerable local, state, and federal interest in restoring flows in the lower reaches of Cowiche Creek.  Low flows have resulted in passage barriers during critical migration periods and the lower reach is often de-watered during the summer months.  There is significant production potential for salmonids if the habitat in the upper reaches were accessible.  Negotiations for water acquisition and alternative water sources are currently underway.

properties.StationDescription: Chumstick Creek flows into the Wenatchee River at river mile 23.5 at the east end of the town of Leavenworth.  This drainage is approximately 47,000 acres in size with mean annual precipitation ranging from 20 inches in the valley bottom to 50 inches in the higher elevations.  The higher elevations are in US Forest Service ownership, while the valley bottom is in private ownership with low-density housing, pasture and agricultural development.  Citizens in the Chumstick watershed initiated a 5-year stream flow-monitoring project to characterize the flow regime of the creek.  This station will continue collecting data to support local decision-making.

The upper portion of the Brender Creek watershed is within US Forest Service property with the lower portion being in private agricultural and residential ownership.  This location is also a TMDL water quality monitoring site.

properties.StationDescription: Mission Creek originates from Mission Ridge, draining 59,609 acres, and flows north emptying into the Wenatchee River at the town of Cashmere at river mile 10.4.  The lowest tributary to the Wenatchee subbasin, the arid environment of the Mission Creek watershed contains many intermittent channels that become dry in mid to late summer.  Approximately 80% of the watershed is managed by the US Forest Service with the remaining 20% in private ownership.  Land use throughout the watershed includes timber harvest, road development, agriculture, residential development, and recreation.  This location is near a TMDL water quality monitoring site.

properties.StationComments: This station was removed on May 17, 2004.

properties.StationDescription: Peshastin Creek originates at Blewett Pass and flows into the Wenatchee River at river mile 17.9, downstream of the town of Peshastin.  Situated in the lower portion of the Wenatchee Subbasin, the Peshastin Creek watershed is more arid than those tributaries closer to the Cascade Crest.  The US Forest Service manages approximately 80% of the watershed with the remaining 20% in private ownership.  Land use includes timber harvest, road development, mining, agriculture, residential development, and recreation.  This station is located approximately one mile from the mouth.

Peshastin Creek originates at Blewett Pass and flows into the Wenatchee River at river mile 17.9, downstream of the town of Peshastin.  This station is location about a mile downstream from the Ingalls Creek confluence at river mile 9.4.  Most of the watershedâ€™s discharge comes from Ingalls Creek, which originates near Mt. Stuart and flows mostly through the Alpine Lakes Wilderness.  When combined with the data from Peshastin Above Ingalls Creek (station 45F110), this station will help determine the flow contribution of Ingalls Creek.

properties.StationDescription: The Chiwaukum Creek watershed is 32,000 acres in size and flows into the Wenatchee River near the head of Tumwater Canyon at RM 35.6, located northwest of the town of Leavenworth.  Most of the drainage lies within the Alpine Lakes Wilderness and is essentially unmanaged.  Salmonid use of Chiwaukum Creek occurs in the lower reach and alluvial fan which supports Chinook and steelhead spawning and rearing.  This location is also a TMDL water quality monitoring site.
properties.StationComments: This station was removed in October 2011 due to budget cuts and regional prioritization.

properties.StationDescription: Nason Creek drains 69,000 acres from the Cascade Crest near Stevens Pass and joins the Wenatchee River just below Lake Wenatchee at RM 53.6.  Spring Chinook, steelhead, sockeye and bull trout spawn and rrear in the Nason creek watershed.  Land use is mixed with timber harvest, road development, rural residential, and high recreational uses.  This site is also a TMDL water quality monitoring site.

The White River drainage encompasses 99,956 acres, much of which is public land in the Wenatchee National Forest.  Originating in alpine glaciers and perennial snow fields within the Glacier Peak Wilderness, the White River is one of two primary tributaries to Lake Wenatchee and a source of the Wenatchee River.  The White and Little Wenatchee rivers are the two primary tributaries to Lake Wenatchee and are the source of the Wenatchee River.  Collectively, they have among the best aquatic habitat anywhere in the Columbia basin with well functioning floodplains and riparian habitat being especially important.
properties.StationComments: Funding for this station is provided by Grant County PUD.

properties.StationName: Ltl Wenatchee R. blw Rainy Cr.
properties.StationDescription: The Little Wenatchee drainage encompasses 64,794 acres, most of which is public land in the Wenatchee National Forest.  The headwaters start at the Cascade Crest and then flow southeast into Lake Wenatchee.  The White and Little Wenatchee rivers are the two primary tributaries to Lake Wenatchee and are the source of the Wenatchee River.  The majority of precipitation falls during the winter months as snow with runoff peaks during late May and early June as snowmelt progresses.  The White and Little Wenatchee rivers have among the best aquatic habitat anywhere in the Columbia basin with well functioning floodplains and riparian habitat being especially important.

properties.StationDescription: The Chiwawa River joins the Wenatchee River near the town of Plain at RM 48.4.  Habitat in the upper portion of the watershed is highly functioning. Rock Creek is a major tributary to the middle reach of the Chiwawa River where there is a strong presence of spring Chinook.  Bull trout spawning populations here, especially in Rock Creek, are among the highest in the mid-Columbia basin.  Human-induced impacts are limited to the alluvial fan of Rock Creek where a habitat improvement project was implemented by the U.S.Forest Service.  Upstream from the alluvial fan, Rock Creek is essentially undisturbed.

properties.StationDescription: Whitepine Creek is one of the largest tributaries to Nason Creek, draining a portion of the eastern slope of the Cascade Crest within US Forest Service ownership.  Steelhead are known to rear in the lowest portion of Whitepine Creek.

properties.StationDescription:
In June 2006, the Washington State Department of Ecology, in cooperation with the Stevens County Public Utility District installed a real-time lake level gage in Loon Lake. This gage is used by Ecology, Stevens County Public Utility District, and Loon Lake Sewer District No. 4 to manage the lake level and estimate needed discharge from the lake during spring and summer months. The maximum lake level of 2381.25ft (NGVD 1929) was fixed by order of the Stevens County Superior Court in February 24th 1950.  This is equal to 2386.33 ft (NGVD 88). The Ecology gage references the lake surface elevation based on the Granite Point bench mark of 2388.73 ft. (NGVD 88).

This gage provides water resource managers and the public an avenue to observe real time lake level conditions. Having this information will help prevent property damage, help estimate water availability, and help determine lake outlet discharges.
properties.StationComments: This station records lake level only. Adjudicated Lake level = 86.33 ft on the graph (NAVD 88 Datum)

properties.StationDescription: The Salmon Creek basin is approximately 18.8 square miles. Originating near Mt. Zion in the Olympic range, Salmon Creek generally drains east to the Strait of Juan De Fuca at the south end of Discovery Bay, immediately west of the mouth of Snow Creek. The geology of the upper basin is predominantly basalt and glacial outwash. It is less vulnerable to mass wasting and erosion than the adjacent Snow Creek headwaters because basalt and breccia underlies this upper canyon reach. The lower valley is characterized by sand, gravel, and clay deposited during glaciation. Material transported from the upper watershed forms a broad alluvial fan. Originally, Salmon Creek was joined by Snow Creek at RM 0.6, but Snow Creek now flows separately to the estuary through an artificial channel. Salmon Creek consists of 8.7 miles of mainstem channel and 21.8 miles of tributary streams.

properties.StationDescription:
The West Fork Campbell Creek streamflow gage is located approximately 200 feet upstream of the Cowlitz County water detention structure.  That structure is the municipal water supply for the town of Ryderwood, Washington.
The watershed upstream of the gage is 3.3 square miles.  The stream begins in the Willapa Hills at around 2600 feet elevation and descends to about 380 feet above sea level at the gage.  The average annual precipitation in the watershed is 83 inches.  Approximately 77 percent of the watershed is forested.
properties.StationComments: This station was decommissioned September 2021.

properties.StationDescription:
The East Fork Campbell Creek streamflow gage is located approximately 200 feet upstream of the Cowlitz County water detention structure.  That structure is the municipal water supply for the town of Ryderwood, Washington.  
The watershed upstream of the gage is 1.8 square miles.  The stream begins in the Willapa Hills at around 1660 feet elevation and descends to about 360 feet above sea level at the gage.  The average annual precipitation in the watershed is 68 inches.  Approximately 71 percent of the watershed is forested.

properties.StationDescription:
The Cowlitz River at Lexington streamflow gage is located in a levee gate vault.  This location provides a reliable measurement of water elevation (â€œstageâ€) for the Cowlitz River. 
 
The levee gate system is a flood control structure that can separate the Cowlitz River and McCorkle Creek.  This structure is operated by the Lexington Flood Control District and helps protect local homes and businesses from high flows in the river and creek.  At times, the gate vault that houses the measurement equipment may be isolated from the Cowlitz River.  When this happens, a banner will be posted to indicate that the stage value may not represent the water elevation in the river.

This streamflow gage is located approximately 9.5 miles upstream of the confluence with the Columbia River.  The watershed upstream of the gage is roughly 2300 square miles.  The river tributaries begin on the slopes of Mount Rainer, Mount St. Helens, and Mount Adams.  The tributaries include the Toutle River, Cispus River, and many smaller streams.   The average annual precipitation in the watershed is 77 inches.  Approximately 62 percent of the watershed is forested.
